extendedMetadata.name: Objective
extendedMetadata.value: LO: 25.4: How did the politics of the 1920s reflect changes in the economy and in American society?

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: POST 25 20

config.question: Sensing the public was tired of the era of reform-minded presidents, what inhibited the Republican administrations of the 1920s from fully returning to traditional Republican policies?

choices.content: the safeguards against such policies that had been put into place by Presidents Roosevelt and Wilson
the new realities of a mass production society
the engagement of America in Europe’s Great War, which paved the way for new trade partners and weakened traditional arguments for high tariffs on imports
the rejection by industry leaders of traditional laissez-faire economic policies

answer_3.response: Consider This: Aware that the public was tired of zealous, reform-minded presidents such as Teddy Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson, Harding and his successors sought a return to traditional Republican policies. See L.O. 25.4 How did the politics of the 1920s reflect changes in the economy and in American society?
